elements.content: A polyfluorinated-aromatic carboxylic acid has been designed and synthesized by the acylation reaction, tetrafluoro-bis­(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)­terephthalamide (H4 bdtfa), which assembled with Zn2+ ions in the mixed solvents of DMF, py, and H2O under solvothermal conditions to produce a two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymer (CP), {[Zn2(bdtfa)­(py)3­(H2O)]­·2DMF} n (1), (py = pyridine, DMF = N,N′-dimethylmethanamide). The final structure has been carefully characterized by various methods including single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), infrared (IR) spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric analysis. Two types of four-coordinated Zn2+ centers present a 2D “sql”-type layer through bdtfa4– ligands, and the adjacent layers are connected through hydrogen bonds and π···π stacking interactions to produce a three-dimensional supramolecular framework. Luminescent results reveal that CP 1 can be regarded as a highly sensitive sensor for detecting nitroaromatics based on the fluorescence quenching effect. Moreover, the reason for the luminescent response of CP 1 toward nitroaromatics has been investigated by theoretical calculations, which indicates that the reason for the quenching can be primarily due to the energy- and electron-transfer as well as the electrostatic interaction between nitroaromatics and CP 1.

The final structure has been carefully characterized by various methods including single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), infrared (IR) spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric analysis. Two types of four-coordinated Zn2+ centers present a 2D "sql"-type layer through bdtfa4- ligands, and the adjacent layers are connected through hydrogen bonds and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions to produce a three-dimensional supramolecular framework. Luminescent results reveal that CP 1 can be regarded as a highly sensitive sensor for detecting nitroaromatics based on the fluorescence quenching effect. Moreover, the reason for the luminescent response of CP 1 toward nitroaromatics has been investigated by theoretical calculations, which indicates that the  reason for the quenching can be primarily due to the energy- and electron-transfer as well as the electrostatic interaction between nitroaromatics and CP 1.

elements.content: A new polyfluorinated-aromatic carboxylic acid was designed and used to construct a luminescent coordination polymer, which can serve as a highly sensitive sensor for detecting nitroaromatic compounds.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

Nitroaromatic compounds, as one kind of important chemical raw material, have been used extensively in various areas including leather and rubber, pharmaceuticals, explosives, and so on; however, the misuse of the nitroaromatic compounds could have a significant impact on the environment, human health, and public safety because of their high toxicity and hazard. Although lots of instrument equipment have been developed to analyze nitroaromatic compounds highly sensitive and selective, they usually require tedious pretreatment process, high expenses, and cumbersome portability. As a result, it is meaningful to investigate inexpensive and convenient probes with high selectivity and sensitivity to monitor nitroaromatic compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

Nitroaromatic compounds, as one kind of important chemical raw material, have been used extensively in various areas including leather and rubber, pharmaceuticals, explosives, and so on; however, the misuse of the nitroaromatic compounds could have a significant impact on the environment, human health, and public safety because of their high toxicity and hazard. Although lots of instrument equipment have been developed to analyze nitroaromatic compounds highly sensitive and selective, they usually require tedious pretreatment process, high expenses, and cumbersome portability. As a result, it is meaningful to investigate inexpensive and convenient probes with high selectivity and sensitivity to monitor nitroaromatic compounds.

elements.content: On the other hand, coordination polymers (CPs) consisting of metal ions/clusters and organic ligands, constitute an interdisciplinary field that has expanded rapidly in the past decade. The nearly limitless choices and combinations of organic linkers and metal centers allow preparation of various structures with interesting properties including but not limited to gas storage and separation, catalysis, chemical sensing, as well as bioimaging and drug delivery. In particular, luminescent CPs have recently bloomed as promising candidates for sensing of numerous analytes because of their inherent advantages over other traditional molecular sensors, such as good crystallinity, defined crystal structure, high surface area and porosity, as well as adjustable and modifiable structure-induced luminescence performance. More importantly, the porosity of CPs could enhance the probability of host–guest interactions by adsorbing and pre-enriching analytes, thus improving the detecting sensitivity and detection limit. In addition, the open metal sites and Lewis acidic and basic sites of organic linkers are readily available for CPs by postsynthetic modifications or predesign of the structures, which may improve the detection selectivity. As a result, lots of luminescent CPs based sensors have been prepared and employed for detecting cations, anions, organic molecules, explosives, environmental toxins, pH, temperature, and biomolecules, and so on.

In addition, the open metal sites and Lewis acidic and basic sites of organic linkers are readily available for CPs by postsynthetic modifications or predesign of the structures, which may improve the detection selectivity. As a result, lots of luminescent CPs based sensors have been prepared and employed for detecting cations, anions, organic molecules, explosives, environmental toxins, pH, temperature, and biomolecules, and so on.

elements.content: In this contribution, we design and synthesize a new polyfluorinated-aromatic ligand, tetrafluoro-bis­(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)­terephthalamide (H4bdtfa) (), containing four coordinated carboxylate groups and two functional amide groups by the acylation reaction of 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoroterephthalic acid and 5-aminoisophthalic acid, to assemble with Zn2+ to construct luminescent CPs for the following considerations: (i) the H4bdtfa ligand could act as a diisophthalic acid linker separated by a tetrafluoro- terephthalamide spacer, the special orientation of isophthalate subunit is in favor of the isolation of porous structures, and the four carboxylate groups can allow the combination of different metal ions to form multidimensional structures. (ii) H4bdtfa could be completely or partially deprotonated to produce abundant acid–base-dependent anions with varying pH values (bdtfa4–, Hbdtfa3–, H2bdtfa2–, and H3bdtfa–), and thus lead to various structures. Moreover, the deprotonated bdtfa4–, Hbdtfa3–, H2bdtfa2–, and H3bdtfa– as well as the high electronegativity fluorine atoms can serve as hydrogen bonds donors and acceptors, which are beneficial to generate supramolecular structures. (iii) Both tetrafluoro-terephthalamide and isophthalate motifs are typical π-conjugate systems, which are favorable to produce π···π stacking interactions, thereby enhancing the stability of the framework. (iv) H4bdtfa is an electron-rich and π-conjugated ligand with good electron-transfer capability, which may improve the sensing ability through host–guest interactions because of hydrogen bonds and π···π interactions. Moreover, the d10 electronic configuration Zn2+ ion and π-conjugated ligands are usually applied to prepare fluorescent materials.

(ii) H4bdtfa could be completely or partially deprotonated to produce abundant acid-base-dependent anions with varying pH values (bdtfa4-, Hbdtfa3-, H2bdtfa2-, and H3bdtfa-), and thus lead to various structures. Moreover, the deprotonated bdtfa4-, Hbdtfa3-, H2bdtfa2-, and H3bdtfa- as well as the high electronegativity fluorine atoms can serve as hydrogen bonds donors and acceptors, which are beneficial to generate supramolecular structures. (iii) Both tetrafluoro-terephthalamide and isophthalate motifs are typical π-conjugate systems, which are favorable to produce π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions, thereby enhancing the stability of the framework. (iv) H4bdtfa is an electron-rich and π-conjugated ligand with good electron-transfer capability, which may improve the sensing ability through host-guest interactions because of hydrogen bonds and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions. Moreover, the d10 electronic configuration Zn2+ ion and π-conjugated ligands are usually applied to prepare fluorescent materials.

elements.content: On the basis of the above considerations, we explored the reactions of H4bdtfa and Zn2+ ions by regulating the ratios of organic linkers and metal centers, reaction solvents, reaction temperature, pH value, etc. Herein, a two-dimensional (2D) CP was obtained under solvothermal conditions, {[Zn2(bdtfa)­(py)3­(H2O)]­·2DMF} n (1), (DMF = N,N′-dimethylmethanamide, py = pyridine). The structure was measured by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, which was further determined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and IR. The results demonstrate that the asymmetric skeleton of 1 has two kinds of Zn2+ centers, one bdtfa4‑– bridging ligand, three coordinated py molecules, one coordinated water molecule, and two uncombined DMF molecules. Two types of Zn2+ centers interconnected through bdtfa4‑– present a “sql”-type 2D layer, and the neighboring layers interact with each other through hydrogen bonds and π···π interactions to form the three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular architecture. The luminescent experiment of 1 has been carried out, which revealed that 1 could act as an excellent sensor to detect nitroaromatics on account of the fluorescence quenching effect. Moreover, the reason for the luminescent response of 1 toward nitroaromatics has been investigated by theoretical calculations.

elements.content: Unless otherwise specified, all reagents are commercially available and have been used directly. The 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra are measured on a Bruker AV-II 500 MHz NMR spectrometer. Elemental analyze data are obtained from a PerkinElmer 2400-II CHNS/O analyzer. IR spectra are collected on a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer with KBr pellets in 4000–400 cm–1. The TG curve is acquired from a NETZSCH TG 209 Setaram apparatus with a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1 under N2 atmosphere. PXRD spectra are carried out on a Bruker D8 Advance instrument with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). The luminescent experiments are finished on an F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Methods and Materials

Unless otherwise specified, all reagents are commercially available and have been used directly. The 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra are measured on a Bruker AV-II 500 MHz NMR spectrometer. Elemental analyze data are obtained from a PerkinElmer 2400-II CHNS/O analyzer. IR spectra are collected on a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer with KBr pellets in 4000-400 cm-1. The TG curve is acquired from a NETZSCH TG 209 Setaram apparatus with a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1 under N2 atmosphere. PXRD spectra are carried out on a Bruker D8 Advance instrument with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). The luminescent experiments are finished on an F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: 2,3,5,6-Tetrafluoroterephthalic acid (2.0 g, 8.4 mmol) and 40.0 mL SOCl2 were added in a 100 mL round-bottomed flask, and the mixture was heated to 95 °C and stirred for 10 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the excess SOCl2 in the mixture was removed by reduced in the rotary evaporator to give the yellow oil. Then 40.0 mL of THF was added into the above oil to harvest solution A. In another 500 mL round-bottomed flask, 5-aminoisophthalic acid (3.1 g, 17.0 mmol) and 180.0 mL of THF were added and stirred at 0 °C, and then solution A was dropwise added, and a yellow precipitate was produced almost immediately. Then 1.0 mL of triethylamine was slowly added and stirred for 12 h at ambient temperature. The volume of THF was reduced in the rotary evaporator and then 80.0 mL of 2 mol·L–1 HCl was added. The precipitate was filtrated and washed with DMF, H2O, and CH3OH, and dried under a vacuum to give a yellow powder (). Yield: ca. 77% (based on 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoroterephthalic acid). Anal. Calcd (%) for C24H12F4N2O10: C 51.08, H 2.14, N 4.96. Found: C 50.97, H 2.23, N 4.88. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 500 MHz, δ/ppm): 13.39 (4H, COOH), 11.61 (2H, ArH), 8.55 (4H, ArH), 8.31 (2H, CONH) (Figure S1); 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6, 125 MHz, δ/ppm): 166.14, 155.65, 143.63, 141.64, 141.54, 138.38, 132.14, 126.01, 123.99, 117.90 (Figure S2). IR (KBr pellets): 3429 (br), 1706 (s), 1677 (s), 1624 (m), 1582 (s), 1479 (s), 1433 (m), 1403 (m), 1350 (m), 1267 (m), 1235 (m), 994 (s), 948 (w), 782 (w), 759 (w), 679 (m) cm–1 (Figure S3).

Synthesis of the H4bdtfa Ligand

After being cooled to room temperature, the excess SOCl2 in the mixture was removed by reduced in the rotary evaporator to give the yellow oil. Then 40.0 mL of THF was added into the above oil to harvest solution A. In another 500 mL round-bottomed flask, 5-aminoisophthalic acid (3.1 g, 17.0 mmol) and 180.0 mL of THF were added and stirred at 0 °C, and then solution A was dropwise added, and a yellow precipitate was produced almost immediately. Then 1.0 mL of triethylamine was slowly added and stirred for 12 h at ambient temperature. The volume of THF was reduced in the rotary evaporator and then 80.0 mL of 2 mol⋅L-1 HCl was added. The precipitate was filtrated and washed with DMF, H2O, and CH3OH, and dried under a vacuum to give a yellow powder (). Yield: ca. 77% (based on 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoroterephthalic acid). Anal. Calcd (%) for C24H12F4N2O10: C 51.08, H 2.14, N 4.96. Found: C 50.97, H 2.23, N 4.88. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 500 MHz, δ/ppm): 13.39 (4H, COOH), 11.61 (2H, ArH), 8.55 (4H, ArH), 8.31 (2H, CONH) (Figure S1); 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6, 125 MHz, δ/ppm): 166.14, 155.65, 143.63, 141.64, 141.54, 138.38, 132.14, 126.01, 123.99, 117.90 (Figure S2). IR (KBr pellets): 3429 (br), 1706 (s), 1677 (s), 1624 (m), 1582 (s), 1479 (s), 1433 (m), 1403 (m), 1350 (m), 1267 (m), 1235 (m), 994 (s), 948 (w), 782 (w), 759 (w), 679 (m) cm-1 (Figure S3).

Synthesis of {[Zn2(bdtfa)(py)3(H2O)]⋅2DMF} n  (1)

Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0592 g, 0.20 mmol) and H4bdtfa (0.0282 g, 0.05 mmol) were added in 5 mL of mixed solvents (H2O/py/DMF = 1:1:8) in a 20 mL vial. Colorless block crystals were obtained after being placed in an oven at 80 °C for 3 days. Yield: ca. 62% (based on H4bdtfa). Anal. Calcd (%) for C45H39F4N7O13Zn2: C 49.47, H 3.60, N 8.97. Found: C 49.59, H 3.68, N 9.03. IR (KBr pellets): 3447 (br), 1686 (m), 1653 (s), 1622 (m), 1561 (m), 1474 (w), 1449 (m), 1434 (w), 1384 (m), 1332 (m), 1202 (m), 1107 (m), 1070 (m), 1046 (m), 996 (m), 781 (m), 761 (m), 734 (m), 697 (m) cm-1 (Figure S3).

elements.content: The crystal 1 was measured on a Bruker Apex-II CCD diffractometer with monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296(2) K. Absorption and scaling correction were undertaken with the SADABS program, and the direct method was used to resolve the crystal structure; except for hydrogen atoms, other atoms were refined by the full-matrix least-squares procedure employing the free Olex2 program embedded with SHELXL-2016. The refinement details for CP 1 have been explained in the CIF document, and the crystallographic data and refinement parameters for 1 have been summarized in (CCDC no. 1852625).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The crystal 1 was measured on a Bruker Apex-II CCD diffractometer with monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296(2) K. Absorption and scaling correction were undertaken with the SADABS program, and the direct method was used to resolve the crystal structure; except for hydrogen atoms, other atoms were refined by the full-matrix least-squares procedure employing the free Olex2 program embedded with SHELXL-2016. The refinement details for CP 1 have been explained in the CIF document, and the crystallographic data and refinement parameters for 1 have been summarized in  (CCDC no. 1852625).

Nitrobenzene (NB) was diluted 100 times with DMF before use. For other nitroaromatic compounds including 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (PA), 2,4-dinitophenol (BNP), o-nitroaniline (oNA), o-nitrophenol (oNP), p-nitroaniline (pNA), p-nitrophenol (pNP), m-nitroaniline (mNA), and m-nitrophenol (mNP), the corresponding 10–2 mol·L–1 analyte solutions were prepared with DMF, respectively. The concentration-dependent intensity test was executed as shown below: soaking 3 mg of CP 1 in 2.0 mL of DMF to disperse evenly with ultrasound, then adding the corresponding 10–2 mol·L–1 solutions containing different nitroaromatic compounds in the above suspension.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Experiments

Nitrobenzene (NB) was diluted 100 times with DMF before use. For other nitroaromatic compounds including 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (PA), 2,4-dinitophenol (BNP), o-nitroaniline (oNA), o-nitrophenol (oNP), p-nitroaniline (pNA), p-nitrophenol (pNP), m-nitroaniline (mNA), and m-nitrophenol (mNP), the corresponding 10-2 mol⋅L-1 analyte solutions were prepared with DMF, respectively. The concentration-dependent intensity test was executed as shown below: soaking 3 mg of CP 1 in 2.0 mL of DMF to disperse evenly with ultrasound, then adding the corresponding 10-2 mol⋅L-1 solutions containing different nitroaromatic compounds in the above suspension.

elements.content: The as-synthesized bulky crystals 1 have a high phase purity, which was proven by comparing the simulated PXRD pattern with the experimental one (Figure S4). Moreover, when immersing 1 in DMF for 3 days, the experimental PXRD pattern is also agreement with the simulated one (Figure S4), indicating the structure of 1 can be maintained in DMF for at least 3 days.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Descriptions

The as-synthesized bulky crystals 1 have a high phase purity, which was proven by comparing the simulated PXRD pattern with the experimental one (Figure S4). Moreover, when immersing 1 in DMF for 3 days, the experimental PXRD pattern is also agreement with the simulated one (Figure S4), indicating the structure of 1 can be maintained in DMF for at least 3 days.

elements.content: Crystal structure results of 1 show that it belongs to the triclinic system with the space group P1̅. In the asymmetric structure (a), there are two Zn2+ centers, one bdtfa4– ligand, three coordinated py molecules, one coordinated water, and two unbounded DMF molecules, and the formula as follows, {[Zn2(bdtfa)­(py)3(H2O)]­·2DMF} n (1). Both two independent Zn2+ ions adopt the four-coordinated tetrahedral geometry. Zn1 is defined by two carboxyl O atoms of two bdtfa4‑– through the bridging mode, one water molecule [Zn1–O: 1.941(4)–1.976(3) Å], and one py molecule [Zn1–N: 2.030(5) Å], whereas the Zn2 center is surrounded by two carboxyl O atoms of two bdtfa4‑– by the bridging mode [Zn2–O: 2.028(4)–2.063(5) Å], and two py molecules [Zn2–N: 2.061(5)–2.068(6) Å] (for the selected bond lengths and angles, see Tables S1 and S2). It is important to note that the bdtfa4– ligand also exhibits two kinds of coordinated orientations because the amide bonds can rotate freely, resulting into two different angles between the two sides of benzene rings and the tetrafluoro-benzene ring (b,c). Neighboring Zn2+ ions are bridged by bdtfa4‑– to produce a 2D layer containing two kinds of rectangular channels in the bc plane, which are occupied by the free DMF molecules (d). To describe the 2D architechture of 1 more clearly, the freely available program TOPOS 5.0 was used to analyze the topological structure. If every Zn2+ ion is regarded as a node and each bdtfa4‑– serves as a linker, CP 1 could simplify as a 4-connected “sql”-type topological structure, and the corresponding Schläfli symbol is {44·62} (e).

elements.content: It is worth noting that many C, N, and O atoms, as well as the high electronegativity F atoms in 1 may be as hydrogen bonds donors and acceptors to produce a supramolecular architecture. Furthermore, the offset arrangements of benzene and pyridine in 1 is opposite to the edge-to-face and face-to-face, which could form strong π···π stacking interactions. As a result, the neighboring layers could stack to give a supramolecular architecture (f) by π···π stacking interactions as well as inter- and intramolecular hydrogen bonds (Table S3).
elements.clean_text: It is worth noting that many C, N, and O atoms, as well as the high electronegativity F atoms in 1 may be as hydrogen bonds donors and acceptors to produce a supramolecular architecture. Furthermore, the offset arrangements of benzene and pyridine in 1 is opposite to the edge-to-face and face-to-face, which could form strong π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions. As a result, the neighboring layers could stack to give a supramolecular architecture (f) by π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions as well as inter- and intramolecular hydrogen bonds (Table S3).

elements.content: CPs constructed from d10 electronic configuration metal centers and π-conjugated organic ligands are generally chosen to evaluate their luminescent properties. In the case of 1, H4bdtfa is a π-conjugated and electron-rich ligand with good electron-transfer ability, and is coordinate with d10 electronic configuration Zn2+ ions, which encourages us to explore its luminescent performance. Therefore, we measured the solid state emission spectrum of 1 at ambient temperature, and it shows one obvious emission band at ca. 458 nm when excited at 356 nm (Figure S5). To explore the origin of the luminescent emission of CP 1, the solid state luminescence spectrum of the free H4 bdtfa ligand has been also carried out at the same conditions (Figure S5). The similar emission band at ca. 388 nm is presented by the H4bdtfa ligand, which may be ascribed to the intraligand emission state of π* → π transition. By comparing the emission spectra of 1 and H4bdtfa, it can be seen that the emission signal of 1 is neither ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) nor metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), which may be mainly ascribed to the d10 configuration Zn2+ center being relatively difficult to reduce or oxidize, and this phenomenon is usually encountered in previous reports. Thus, the luminescent emission of 1 could be mainly due to the intraligand charge transfer transition. Moreover, the luminescence intensity of 1 is slightly enhanced, which can be explained in that the ligand binds to the mental center to increase the rigidity compared with the free H4bdtfa ligand, therefore decreasing the energy loss of radiation-less decay. In addition, the luminescent emission spectrum of 1 is distinctly red-shifted compared with the free H4bdtfa ligand, manifesting the existence of coordination interactions among the H4bdtfa ligand and Zn2+ centers.

Luminescent Properties

CPs constructed from d10 electronic configuration metal centers and π-conjugated organic ligands are generally chosen to evaluate their luminescent properties. In the case of 1, H4bdtfa is a π-conjugated and electron-rich ligand with good electron-transfer ability, and is coordinate with d10 electronic configuration Zn2+ ions, which encourages us to explore its luminescent performance. Therefore, we measured the solid state emission spectrum of 1 at ambient temperature, and it shows one obvious emission band at ca. 458 nm when excited at 356 nm (Figure S5). To explore the origin of the luminescent emission of CP 1, the solid state luminescence spectrum of the free H4 bdtfa ligand has been also carried out at the same conditions (Figure S5). The similar emission band at ca. 388 nm is presented by the H4bdtfa ligand, which may be ascribed to the intraligand emission state of π* → π transition. By comparing the emission spectra of 1 and H4bdtfa, it can be seen that the emission signal of 1 is neither ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) nor metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), which may be mainly ascribed to the d10 configuration Zn2+ center being relatively difficult to reduce or oxidize, and this phenomenon is usually encountered in previous reports. Thus, the luminescent emission of 1 could be mainly due to the intraligand charge transfer transition. Moreover, the luminescence intensity of 1 is slightly enhanced, which can be explained in that the ligand binds to the mental center to increase the rigidity compared with the free H4bdtfa ligand, therefore decreasing the energy loss of radiation-less decay. In addition, the luminescent emission spectrum of 1 is distinctly red-shifted compared with the free H4bdtfa ligand, manifesting the existence of coordination interactions among the H4bdtfa ligand and Zn2+ centers.

elements.content: Previous results suggest that the energy and electron could transfer from electron-donating complex to high electron-withdrawing nitro-compound under photoexcitation, which usually results in the fluorescence being weakened or completely quenched. From the structural descriptions of 1, the π···π interactions and hydrogen bonds could strengthen the interactions between analytes and target compound, and thus improve the sensing ability. Therefore, the electron-withdrawing nitroaromatic compounds containing NB, PA, BNP, oNA, oNP, mNA, mNP, pNA, and pNP are chosen to assess the luminescent sensitivity of 1.

elements.content: The luminescent experiments of concentration-dependent intensity are executed by slowly adding different amounts of nitroaromatic compounds into the well-dispersed suspensions of 1, and the concentration-dependent intensity for NB is selected as a representative of the specific description. The emission intensity decreases as gradually adding NB, almost quenched when the amount of NB attains 200 μL (1091 ppm) (a), and the quenching efficiency is 93.4%. The quenching efficiency of NB can be assessed by employing the Stern–Volmer (S–V) equation, I 0/I – 1 = K SV[M], in which I 0 and I are the emission intensities of maximum emission band before and after the addition of NB, respectively, [M] represents the molar concentration of the NB analyte (mM), and K SV is the S–V constant (M–1). The maximum emission intensities at ca. 425 nm versus the concentration of NB analyte are plotted and presented in b. When the concentration of NB is lower than 0.02 mM, the S–V curve is nearly linear, and the detection limit can be calculated to be 9.15 × 10–7 mol·L–1 by the equation 3 σ/k, in which σ is the standard deviation of luminescent intensities of 10 field blanks, and k is the slope. However, when concentration of NB is higher than 0.02 mM, the S–V curve is an apparent deviation from linearity, which may be mainly due to the presence of self-absorption and/or the dynamic quenching and static quenching resulting from the energy-transfer process. In order to assess the whole concentration, we employ an exponential S–V formula, I 0/I = a·exp­(k[M]) + b, in which I 0 and I are the maximum emission intensities before and after adding NB, respectively, [M] represents the concentration of NB­(mM), and a, b, and k are constants. The results demonstrate that the whole range could match well with the equation I 0/I = 1.167·exp­(28.860­[M]) – 1.121 (b), and the quenching constant of NB is 3.368 × 104 L·mol–1 calculated from the fitted values of a and k.

In order to explore the reason for the fluorescence response of selected nitroaromatics, the response of 1 toward selected nitroaromatics was investigated. First, the quenching probability caused by the structural breakage of 1 could be readily ruled out from PXRD experiments and IR spectra (Figures S4 and S6), considering that the luminescent signal of 1 primarily comes from the intraligand charge transfer transition of the H4 bdtfa ligand. Therefore, the molecular orbitals of 1 are approximately computed with the H4bdtfa ligand. The energy values for highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of selected nitroaromatic compounds and H4bdtfa ligand are calculated by the density functional theory at the B3LYP level (). The results suggest that the LUMO energy of the selective nitroaromatic compounds is smaller, and the quenching potency is larger. The quenching potency of PA is highest among selected nitroaromatic compounds, which may be due to that the excited state electrons are most easily transferred from the conduction bands of H4 bdtfa to the LUMO orbital of PA since the lowest LUMO energy, However, the order of quenching constants of selected nitroaromatic compounds is not completely consistent with the energy of LUMO orbitals, manifesting that the electron-transfer may be not the only factor of the luminescent response. The electrostatic interactions and/or energy transfer may be other possible reasons and be responsible for the luminescent response, which is also supported by the exponential S–V curves. Indeed, many C, N, O and high electronegativity F atoms coexist in 1, which can serve as hydrogen bonds acceptors and donors to increase the interactions between nitroaromatic compounds and CP 1. Furthermore, the π···π stacking interactions in 1 also interact with nitroaromatics through the host–guest interactions. Consequently, the electron transfer and electrostatic interactions as well as energy-transfer can easily happen between nitroaromatic compounds and the framework of 1, leading to the luminescent intensity weakening or even quenching.

elements.content: In addition, the possible reason that PA has the largest quenching constant among the selected nitroaromatics can be attributed to the following two aspects: first, the energy of LUMO for PA is the lowest, which permits electron and energy-transfer from the framework of 1 to PA molecules to be the easiest and makes the luminescent response most obvious. On the other hand, the PA molecule possessing more −OH and −NO2 groups could participate in the formation of hydrogen bonds with 1 stronger than other nitroaromatic compounds, the host–guest interaction between 1 and PA may be stronger, and therefore the electrostatic interaction can take place more easily.

elements.content: In conclusion, a new polyfluorinated-aromatic carboxylic acid ligand was designed and prepared by the typical acylation reaction, which was further employed to react with Zn2+ ions to construct a 2D CP under the solvothermal conditions. The crystal structure demonstrates that two kinds of tetrahedral Zn2+ centers are bridged through bdtfa4– to produce a 2D “sql” topological structure, which further generates a 3D supramolecular architecture by π···π interactions and hydrogen bonds. Importantly, CP 1 can be regarded as a highly sensitive probe for detecting nitroaromatic compounds. Furthermore, the luminescent response of 1 toward nitroaromatic compounds has been preliminarily investigated by theoretical calculations, and the reason could be primarily ascribed to energy- and electron-transfer and electrostatic interaction between nitroaromatic compounds and CP 1.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, a new polyfluorinated-aromatic carboxylic acid ligand was designed and prepared by the typical acylation reaction, which was further employed to react with Zn2+ ions to construct a 2D CP under the solvothermal conditions. The crystal structure demonstrates that two kinds of tetrahedral Zn2+ centers are bridged through bdtfa4- to produce a 2D "sql" topological structure, which further generates a 3D supramolecular architecture by π⋅⋅⋅π interactions and hydrogen bonds. Importantly, CP 1 can be regarded as a highly sensitive probe for detecting nitroaromatic compounds. Furthermore, the luminescent response of 1 toward nitroaromatic compounds has been preliminarily investigated by theoretical calculations, and the reason could be primarily ascribed to energy- and electron-transfer and electrostatic interaction between nitroaromatic compounds and CP 1.

2,3,5,6-Tetrafluoroterephthalic acid (2.0 g, 8.4 mmol) and 40.0 mL SOCl2 were added in a 100 mL round-bottomed flask, and the mixture was heated to 95 °C and stirred for 10 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the excess SOCl2 in the mixture was removed by reduced in the rotary evaporator to give the yellow oil. Then 40.0 mL of THF was added into the above oil to harvest solution A. In another 500 mL round-bottomed flask, 5-aminoisophthalic acid (3.1 g, 17.0 mmol) and 180.0 mL of THF were added and stirred at 0 °C, and then solution A was dropwise added, and a yellow precipitate was produced almost immediately. Then 1.0 mL of triethylamine was slowly added and stirred for 12 h at ambient temperature. The volume of THF was reduced in the rotary evaporator and then 80.0 mL of 2 mol·L–1 HCl was added. The precipitate was filtrated and washed with DMF, H2O, and CH3OH, and dried under a vacuum to give a yellow powder (). Yield: ca. 77% (based on 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoroterephthalic acid). Anal. Calcd (%) for C24H12F4N2O10: C 51.08, H 2.14, N 4.96. Found: C 50.97, H 2.23, N 4.88. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 500 MHz, δ/ppm): 13.39 (4H, COOH), 11.61 (2H, ArH), 8.55 (4H, ArH), 8.31 (2H, CONH) (Figure S1); 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6, 125 MHz, δ/ppm): 166.14, 155.65, 143.63, 141.64, 141.54, 138.38, 132.14, 126.01, 123.99, 117.90 (Figure S2). Colorless block crystals were obtained after being placed in an oven at 80 °C for 3 days. Yield: ca. 62% (based on H4bdtfa). Anal. Calcd (%) for C45H39F4N7O13Zn2: C 49.47, H 3.60, N 8.97. Found: C 49.59, H 3.68, N 9.03. IR (KBr pellets): 3447 (br), 1686 (m), 1653 (s), 1622 (m), 1561 (m), 1474 (w), 1449 (m), 1434 (w), 1384 (m), 1332 (m), 1202 (m), 1107 (m), 1070 (m), 1046 (m), 996 (m), 781 (m), 761 (m), 734 (m), 697 (m) cm–1 (Figure S3).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the H4bdtfa Ligand

2,3,5,6-Tetrafluoroterephthalic acid (2.0 g, 8.4 mmol) and 40.0 mL SOCl2 were added in a 100 mL round-bottomed flask, and the mixture was heated to 95 °C and stirred for 10 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the excess SOCl2 in the mixture was removed by reduced in the rotary evaporator to give the yellow oil. Then 40.0 mL of THF was added into the above oil to harvest solution A. In another 500 mL round-bottomed flask, 5-aminoisophthalic acid (3.1 g, 17.0 mmol) and 180.0 mL of THF were added and stirred at 0 °C, and then solution A was dropwise added, and a yellow precipitate was produced almost immediately. Then 1.0 mL of triethylamine was slowly added and stirred for 12 h at ambient temperature. The volume of THF was reduced in the rotary evaporator and then 80.0 mL of 2 mol⋅L-1 HCl was added. The precipitate was filtrated and washed with DMF, H2O, and CH3OH, and dried under a vacuum to give a yellow powder (). Yield: ca. 77% (based on 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoroterephthalic acid). Anal. Calcd (%) for C24H12F4N2O10: C 51.08, H 2.14, N 4.96. Found: C 50.97, H 2.23, N 4.88. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 500 MHz, δ/ppm): 13.39 (4H, COOH), 11.61 (2H, ArH), 8.55 (4H, ArH), 8.31 (2H, CONH) (Figure S1); 13C NMR (DMSO-d 6, 125 MHz, δ/ppm): 166.14, 155.65, 143.63, 141.64, 141.54, 138.38, 132.14, 126.01, 123.99, 117.90 (Figure S2). IR (KBr pellets): 3429 (br), 1706 (s), 1677 (s), 1624 (m), 1582 (s), 1479 (s), 1433 (m), 1403 (m), 1350 (m), 1267 (m), 1235 (m), 994 (s), 948 (w), 782 (w), 759 (w), 679 (m) cm-1 (Figure S3).

Synthesis of {[Zn2(bdtfa)(py)3(H2O)]⋅2DMF} n  (1)

Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0592 g, 0.20 mmol) and H4bdtfa (0.0282 g, 0.05 mmol) were added in 5 mL of mixed solvents (H2O/py/DMF = 1:1:8) in a 20 mL vial. Colorless block crystals were obtained after being placed in an oven at 80 °C for 3 days. Yield: ca. 62% (based on H4bdtfa). Anal. Calcd (%) for C45H39F4N7O13Zn2: C 49.47, H 3.60, N 8.97. Found: C 49.59, H 3.68, N 9.03. IR (KBr pellets): 3447 (br), 1686 (m), 1653 (s), 1622 (m), 1561 (m), 1474 (w), 1449 (m), 1434 (w), 1384 (m), 1332 (m), 1202 (m), 1107 (m), 1070 (m), 1046 (m), 996 (m), 781 (m), 761 (m), 734 (m), 697 (m) cm-1 (Figure S3).

cln_elements.content: CPs constructed from d10 electronic configuration metal centers and π-conjugated organic ligands are generally chosen to evaluate their luminescent properties. In the case of 1, H4bdtfa is a π-conjugated and electron-rich ligand with good electron-transfer ability, and is coordinate with d10 electronic configuration Zn2+ ions, which encourages us to explore its luminescent performance. Therefore, we measured the solid state emission spectrum of 1 at ambient temperature, and it shows one obvious emission band at ca. 458 nm when excited at 356 nm (Figure S5). To explore the origin of the luminescent emission of CP 1, the solid state luminescence spectrum of the free H4 bdtfa ligand has been also carried out at the same conditions (Figure S5). The similar emission band at ca. 388 nm is presented by the H4bdtfa ligand, which may be ascribed to the intraligand emission state of π* → π transition. By comparing the emission spectra of 1 and H4bdtfa, it can be seen that the emission signal of 1 is neither ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) nor metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), which may be mainly ascribed to the d10 configuration Zn2+ center being relatively difficult to reduce or oxidize, and this phenomenon is usually encountered in previous reports. Thus, the luminescent emission of 1 could be mainly due to the intraligand charge transfer transition. Moreover, the luminescence intensity of 1 is slightly enhanced, which can be explained in that the ligand binds to the mental center to increase the rigidity compared with the free H4bdtfa ligand, therefore decreasing the energy loss of radiation-less decay. In addition, the luminescent emission spectrum of 1 is distinctly red-shifted compared with the free H4bdtfa ligand, manifesting the existence of coordination interactions among the H4bdtfa ligand and Zn2+ centers.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

CPs constructed from d10 electronic configuration metal centers and π-conjugated organic ligands are generally chosen to evaluate their luminescent properties. In the case of 1, H4bdtfa is a π-conjugated and electron-rich ligand with good electron-transfer ability, and is coordinate with d10 electronic configuration Zn2+ ions, which encourages us to explore its luminescent performance. Therefore, we measured the solid state emission spectrum of 1 at ambient temperature, and it shows one obvious emission band at ca. 458 nm when excited at 356 nm (Figure S5). To explore the origin of the luminescent emission of CP 1, the solid state luminescence spectrum of the free H4 bdtfa ligand has been also carried out at the same conditions (Figure S5). The similar emission band at ca. 388 nm is presented by the H4bdtfa ligand, which may be ascribed to the intraligand emission state of π* → π transition. By comparing the emission spectra of 1 and H4bdtfa, it can be seen that the emission signal of 1 is neither ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) nor metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT), which may be mainly ascribed to the d10 configuration Zn2+ center being relatively difficult to reduce or oxidize, and this phenomenon is usually encountered in previous reports. Thus, the luminescent emission of 1 could be mainly due to the intraligand charge transfer transition. Moreover, the luminescence intensity of 1 is slightly enhanced, which can be explained in that the ligand binds to the mental center to increase the rigidity compared with the free H4bdtfa ligand, therefore decreasing the energy loss of radiation-less decay. In addition, the luminescent emission spectrum of 1 is distinctly red-shifted compared with the free H4bdtfa ligand, manifesting the existence of coordination interactions among the H4bdtfa ligand and Zn2+ centers.
